bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, March 2, 1938

div1.p: Andrus sends Hench his medical history and wonders if his spinal condition is a result of yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Philip Showalter Hench, March 2, 1938
div1.opener:
J.H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
3-2-38.
Leave on desk
P871.
Dr. Philip S. Hench,
% Mayo Clinic,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Am just in receipt of air-mail letter from our friend, Moran,
in which he quotes from your recent letter to him.

First, I want you to know how very much I appreciate your in-
terest in my case and to assure you that there is not the
remotest possibility of your becoming involved in a dispute
relative diagnosis. I believe the enclosed letter from my
son will clarify that point.

From the fact that you are a specialist on arthritis and that
you are conducting research among Major Reed's yellow fever
volunteers, it has occured to me that you may be investigating
the possibility that spinal affliction may be an aftermath of
yellow fever.

Remembering Kissinger's case, I attempted to ascertain if any
other volunteers had had similar trouble. Was unable to
find anything to advance the theory.

In addition to the letter from my son, am enclosing detailed
“case history” - from the layman's point of view - which you
may find useful.

In the event my case holds sufficient scientific interest for
you so that you would like to make an examination, I shall be
glad to see you at any time.

Again thanking you and assuring you of my readiness to assist
you in any way possible, I am

closer.seg:
Postscript - Can you advise me as to the most suitable type of
mattress for my hospital-type bed? I am using hair mattress
which “packs” quickly. It seems that I feel better and have
less pain before mattress becomes packed. Do you know any-
thing of the suitability of sponge rubber mattresses for spinal
cases?
JHA
